report_title: Canned Fruit & Vegetable Processing Industry Report
executive_summary: The Canned Fruit and Vegetable Processing industry often performs countercyclically to the US economy, benefiting it in times of economic uncertainty. During periods of growth, consumers shy away from canned fruit and vegetable products as higher levels of disposable income enable them to trade up to pricier and fresher products. The perception that canned and processed food is less nutritious than fresh and unprocessed food has been a substantial inhibitor of industry expansion in recent years, especially as health consciousness rises. Producers have responded by diversifying product lines to include canned goods with zero added sugars, low-sodium or organic ingredients. Still, there is little opportunity for product innovation in canned fruit and vegetable processing, leaving companies to compete on price and quality.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Bulk-Food Wholesalers Inundate the US Grocery Scene
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The COVID-19 pandemic precipitated a trend of buying food in bulk as many consumers feared food shortages amid lockdowns and the general uncertainty of the early days of the pandemic. Wholesale grocers such as Costco and Sam's Club satisfied this shift in consumer preferences and drove consumers to stock up on canned food. Recent inflationary pressures exacerbated the bulk-food trend and boosted sales of canned fruit and vegetable products.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Canned Produce Gets a Bad Rap
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The negative perception associated with canned and processed food by most consumers has been producers' largest road block on the way to growth. According to a 2021 survey by the International Food Information Council, 29.0% of consumers are less likely to purchase a food or beverage if it is processed, while 23.0% reported that it depends on the type of food. Foods high in protein are the most popular processed foods to buy.

In recent years, organic food and beverage sales in both developed and emerging economies have been growing at a faster rate than most other grocery segments. This has presented an opportunity for Canned Fruit and Vegetable Processors. New companies have continued to enter the Canned Fruit and Vegetable Processing industry to take advantage of the growing demand for organic fruits and vegetables.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Imports Taper Off While Demand from Emerging Markets Grows
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Moving forward substantial declines in the value of the US dollar are expected to raise the relative cost of canned products from Mexico, China and Canada, relieving pressure from import competition. More organic movements abroad will present an opportunity for exports. Emerging economies, such as India, are promoting organic farming, which will leave room for domestic companies to supplement organic canned goods during low yields.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Organic Growth To Slow But Opportunity Remains
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The effects of the continued rise of organic are twofold: some consumers will increasingly substitute canned produce with fresh, while others will reach for canned goods for the first time. The advantages of an organic label will differ by product segment. Organic produce isn't expected to succeed as much as organic soups, sauces, jams and pickles, all of which have fewer healthier substitutes. Organic food sales grew to $57.5 billion in 2021, according to the Organic Trade Association, outpacing many conventional grocery foods. As this trend continues, organic food will continue to provide room for growth in coming years.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Cost Of Commodities Continues To Rise
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The price of fruit and vegetables will be volatile in the coming years. This uncertain operating environment will impact processors' ability to earn consistent margins. Fruit and vegetable processors will look to wages to as a means of cutting costs. Due to the Ukraine-Russia war, the price of fertilizer is expected to remain elevated in the period as Russia remains one of the largest producers of fertilizer, which complicates prices in the period as many countries, including the US, have imposed sanctions on the country. The elevated cost of fertilizer, while possibly passed along to consumers in the form of higher prices, could also impact profit for canned fruit and vegetable processors in the coming years.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry purchase fruits and vegetables and process them with other ingredients to create a variety of food products including canned juices, canned soups (except seafood), jams, baby food, sauces and dehydrated fruits and vegetables. The final products are then packaged and sold to consumers at various retail channels. This industry does not include frozen fruits and vegetables, which are discussed in IBISWorld report 31141.

threats: Per capita fruit and vegetable consumption

key_trends: Canned fruit and vegetable processors found temporary relief from COVID-19, which prompted consumers to stockpile canned goods.
Canned fruit and vegetable sales' long-term downward trend briefly reversed in 2020.

Favorable economic conditions drive consumers toward fresh and ready-made products, which are commonly perceived as more nutritious than canned goods. When disposable income levels rise, consumers trade up for fresh produce.
The organic market presents a glimmer of hope for struggling canned fruit and vegetable producers. An influx of new processors emerged to capitalize on this rapidly growing market.
COVID-19 assistance contributed to already inflated sales. Stockpiling and low consumer confidence in 2020 underpinned the industry's only year of growth during the five-year period.

The rise of organic has prompted a slew of new regulations surrounding labeling and ingredients. The USDA requires food processors to label canned goods according to the number of organic ingredients used and to display all product modifications.
Wholesale grocers provide a promising market for canned fruit and vegetable processors. Consumers tend to stock up on canned food,
Canned fruit and vegetable sales are subject to economic fluctuations
Health consciousness tempers sales of sugar-loaded juices
Processors are responding by producing more natural fruit and vegetable juices.
Canned fruit and vegetable processors settle near upstream suppliers
Suppliers thrive in the West's temperate climate.
Having proximity to suppliers lowers transportation costs.
Populous regions provide a steady market for processors
The number of supermarkets and grocery stores tends to be higher in more populated areas.
Nearby processors get access to more shelf space.
Price competition prevents significant market domination
Canned produce is known for being economical.
Price is a considerable basis of competition for canned fruit and vegetable processors.
Familiar brands attract consumers and acquire critical shelf space
Industry frontrunner Campbell Soup Company has a loyal customer base.
Campbell's diverse product portfolio gives the company an in with supermarkets and grocery stores.
A stigma against canned fruit and vegetable products opens the door for competitors
Many consumers believe canned products to be nutritionally inferior to fresh produce and soups, despite evidence to the contrary.
This heightens external competition.
Amid sluggish domestic demand, prominent processors are looking abroad

market_segmentation.segment_description: Nearly half of all canned fruit and vegetable products go directly to grocery store shelves. Grocery stores and fruit and vegetable markets make up the retail channel. Small- and medium-sized companies have a harder time gaining access to shelf space, often selling products in smaller retail channels or to other markets.

Fruit and vegetables are sold at the wholesale level through superstores and bulk food stores. Bulk food stores (Costco, BJ's Wholesale Club, Sam's Club) are becoming more pervasive in car-friendly cities and suburbs across the United States. The COVID-19 pandemic precipitated a trend of buying food in bulk as many sought to stock up on essentials amid the uncertainty of the early days of lockdowns.

Food service channels include restaurants and drinking places. The pandemic crippled restaurants and bars as consumers turned to grocery stores for food options. Since then, bars and restaurants have been on the road to recovery.
Households and other miscellaneous customers occasionally purchase canned goods directly from manufacturers.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Dried and Dehydrated Fruits and Vegetables
products_and_services.product_description: Dried and Dehydrated Fruits and Vegetables

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Canned fruits and vegetables replace fresh produce in times of economic distress
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Fruits and vegetables are canned through a variety of methods that reduce the perishability of the product. Canned produce offers a convenient, low-cost and shelf-stable alternative to fresh fruits and vegetables. As the cost of fruits and vegetables increases, consumers often switch out fresh produce for canned.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: The pandemic bolstered soups, stews and bouillon
demand_determinants.determinant_description: This segment consists of dry, canned soup, wet soup, broth and bouillon cubes. Soups and stews thrived during the COVID-19 pandemic, when consumers sought cost-effective and long-lasting food.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Ketchup and tomato-based sauces are essential pantry items
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Ketchup and other sauces, such as pasta sauce, chili and salsa make up this segment. Salsas have gained popularity as Mexican cuisine has expanded across the nation. Ketchup and pasta sauces are considered staples in many US households, which shields this segment from seasonal or economic downturns.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Low-cost operations abroad impede domestic processors
international_trade_points.trade_description: China benefits from low labor and regulation costs, which enable Chinese producers to charge lower prices. An inflated US dollar has aggravated this trend. Substantial food safety and sanitation regulations from the US government force domestic processors to choose between lowering prices or salvaging profit.
Duty-free trade through the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) enables Mexico and Canada to compete with low-priced goods from China and Thailand.

international_trade_points.trade_title: International demand for canned produce falls short
international_trade_points.trade_description: A strong US dollar encourages foreign markets to seek canned produce outside of the United States. Globally, consumers increasingly prefer fresh food over canned produce, jams and soups.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Industry frontrunners fixate on foreign operations
international_trade_points.trade_description: Lofty transportation costs convince domestic producers to move abroad to reach international markets.

business_locations.location_description: A temperate climate makes the West the ideal home for fruit and vegetable farmers. Produce processors locate near these farms to reduce transportation costs.

The Great Lakes region is home to a substantial portion of the US population and many grocery wholesalers. Due to its proximity to Canada, the Great Lakes is an optimal location for exporters of canned and processed produce.

Canned fruit and vegetable processers often seek out locations near distributors to foster positive relationships and cost-effective contracts. The Southeast houses more than one-quarter of the US population, attracting many grocery wholesalers and retailers to the area.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Wheat, feed grains, cotton, rice and other crop farmers benefit from agricultural subsidies, which ultimately limit the production of fruits and vegetables. A scarce supply of fruits and vegetables raises the price of these canned produce, discouraging consumers from purchasing the typically budget-friendly products.

Signed into law in 2011, the act seeks to mitigate foodborne diseases by enforcing food safety regulations throughout multiple points in the global supply chain. Canned fruit and vegetable processors endure stringent sanitation requirements, inspections and sometimes recalls, which can disrupt operations and raise costs.

According to the FDA's food labeling guide, processors of canned produce are required to prominently display the product description on the can, the country of origin and any product modifications. Nutritional information and an ingredient list must be displayed on the back of the can. Also, juice products that contain less than 100.0% juice must feature a qualifier, such as drink or cocktail, in the name.

The USDA allows for varying degrees of organic food products depending on whether the product is 100.0%, 95.0%, 70.0% or less than 70.0% organic. Label requirements differ by the number of organic ingredients used in the production process. Canned fruit and vegetable products can generally be labeled 100.0% organic if they are raw, unprocessed or minimally processed.

regulations_points.regulation_title: THE NATIONAL BIOENGINEERED FOOD DISCLOSURE LAW
regulations_points.regulation_description: In 2016, Congress further tightened food labeling regulations by requiring all canned and packaged foods to state whether they are genetically modified. The law permits small QR codes or symbols, which can be a tactic used by producers to dodge consumer skepticism of genetically engineered products.

Canned fruit and vegetable processors were considered essential businesses during COVID-19 in 2020. While they were permitted to continue operating, processing facilities were subject to increased scrutiny regarding sanitation and social distancing.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Smaller, financially strapped operators are more dependent on labor to perform canning and processing tasks, while larger companies can rely more on equipment and machinery.

basis_points.basis_description: Price competition prevents significant market domination. Since canned produce is known for being economical, price is a considerable basis of competition for canned fruit and vegetable processors.

Familiar brands attract consumers and acquire critical shelf space. Industry frontrunner Campbell Soup Company has a loyal customer base and a diverse product portfolio that gives the company an in with supermarkets and grocery stores.

A stigma against canned fruit and vegetable products opens the door for competitors. Many consumers believe canned products to be nutritionally inferior to fresh produce and soups, which heightens external competition, despite evidence to the contrary.

concentration_points.concentration_description: A handful of household brands possess nearly 40.0% of the market for canned fruits and vegetables, leaving nearly 4,000 other companies to compete for the remaining market.
Multinational companies typically offer a wide range of products, giving them easier access to store shelves and various geographic regions.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: UTILITY COSTS ARE SUBSTANTIAL FOR PROCESSING FACILITIES
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Processing canned fruit and vegetable products require ample electric power, water and other utilities. In 2023, utility costs account for 1.5% of revenue.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: LONG-TERM CONTRACTS WITH SUPPLIERS KEEP PURCHASE COSTS STEADY
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Key input prices, such as produce and dairy products, are subject to fluctuations based on demand for raw materials, changes in crop size, weather conditions and energy costs. Even as fruit and vegetable prices rose, purchase costs remained stable since most processors developed long-term contracts with upstream suppliers. Purchase costs account for 50.5% of revenue in 2023.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: THE EMERGENCE OF SMALL-SCALE PROCESSORS DRIVES UP WAGE COSTS
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: A boom in specialty and organic food has precipitated a wave of new canned fruit and vegetable processors with fewer capital resources and more significant wage expenses. Wages are rising even among established companies as diminishing demand limits their ability to purchase new capital. Wage expenses account for 10.2% of revenue in 2023, up from an estimated 9.7% in 2018.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: PROFIT IS SQUEEZED BY RISING COSTS AND STAGNANT DEMAND
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Canned fruit and vegetable product sales surged amid COVID-19, leading consumers to stockpile shelf-stable items. The pandemic also increased operating costs though, neutralizing any potential benefits. Commodity prices skyrocketed after the pandemic as demand eclipsed supply. Inflated purchase costs squeezed profit. As health consciousness rises, domestic consumers are shifting away from canned fruit and vegetable products. This sluggish demand is hurting profit for goods that are already low-margin. In 2023, profit is anticipated to comprise 1.4% of revenue.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Smaller, financially strapped operators are more dependent on labor
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Smaller, financially strapped operators are more dependent on labor to perform canning and processing tasks, while larger companies can rely more on equipment and machinery.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low levels of innovation limit the threat to incumbent operators
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Low levels of innovation limit the threat to incumbent operators from new technologies disrupting their operations. However, a low rate of growth in technology can also create exposure for incumbents as the trajectory of innovation in other markets could lead to unforeseen competitive disadvantages.

The major markets for this industry are highly concentrated, which implies that the market has a focus on key customer segments. This presents an opportunity for strategic entrance into lower-end markets or unserved markets for innovations to take on a disruptive trajectory.

volatility_points.volatility_title: CANNED PRODUCE LOSES OUT TO FRESH PRODUCE
volatility_points.volatility_description: The Canned Fruit and Vegetable Processing industry struggles with consistent declines as positive economic conditions discourage the purchase of budget-friendly canned produce while rising health consciousness drives consumer preferences for fresh produce. Consumers often perceive canned produce to be less healthy than fresh since it is processed, which has fueled the narrative that canned produce contain less nutrients. These claims have been debunked by health experts, but remain an impediment to the industry's expansion.

Canned fruit and vegetable processors struggled to keep up with the abnormal demand for canned produce in 2020. Plummeting consumer confidence sent droves of people to the grocery store to stockpile nonperishable items to endure the indefinite stay-at-home orders.

volatility_points.volatility_title: INCONSISTENT HARVESTS SPUR VOLATILITY IN COMMODITY PRICES
volatility_points.volatility_description: Canned fruit and vegetable processors are subject to upstream volatility in the prices of fruits and vegetables. Inconsistent harvests can squeeze supplies and drive up prices, or lead to an excess of product and send prices tumbling. A fruit index spike in 2022 as a result of pent-up demand is followed by a price decline in 2023 as supply and demand normalize.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: CANNED FRUITS AND VEGETABLES REPLACE FRESH PRODUCE IN TIMES OF ECONOMIC DISTRESS
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Fruits and vegetables are canned through a variety of methods that reduce the perishability of the product. Canned produce offers a convenient, low-cost and shelf-stable alternative to fresh fruits and vegetables. As the cost of fruits and vegetables increases, consumers often switch out fresh produce for canned.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: THE PANDEMIC BOLSTERED SOUPS, STEWS AND BOUILLON
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: This segment consists of dry, canned soup, wet soup, broth and bouillon cubes. Soups and stews thrived during the COVID-19 pandemic, when consumers sought cost-effective and long-lasting food.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: KETCHUP AND TOMATO-BASED SAUCES ARE ESSENTIAL PANTRY ITEMS
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Ketchup and other sauces, such as pasta sauce, chili and salsa make up this segment. Salsas have gained popularity as Mexican cuisine has expanded across the nation. Ketchup and pasta sauces are considered staples in many US households, which shields this segment from seasonal or economic downturns.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: ADDED SUGARS IN FRUIT AND VEGETABLE JUICES CURB SALES
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: This segment includes canned, bagged and boxed juices, nectars and concentrates that are diluted with water before drinking. Consumers are growing wary of beverages with added sugars, evidenced by the steadily declining sales of orange juice over the last decade.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: DRIED AND DEHYDRATED FRUITS AND VEGETABLES PRESENT OPPORTUNITIES FOR PRODUCT INNOVATION
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: These products include dried and dehydrated fruit snacks (strawberries and blueberries) and are typically used as ingredients in cooking or consumed as snacks. Companies have rolled out new dried fruit and vegetable products, including dried super fruits, in response to rising health consciousness.

FAQs.question: How is your company impacted by rising imports from abroad?
FAQs.answer: Import penetration is not high, but has increased as consumers have demanded more fruits and vegetables not native to US climates.

FAQs.question: Has global supply chain disruption amid the pandemic affected demand for your products?
FAQs.answer: Exports are expected to decrease as global supply chains are disrupted amid the pandemic.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Processed fruits and vegetables are often inferior goods that consumers may purchase more of during an economic downturn.

FAQs.question: Is your company located in proximity to important suppliers?
FAQs.answer: Locating canning facilities close to agricultural sources helps lower cost in addition to boosting quality.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing heavily in R&D to meet changing consumer preferences?
FAQs.answer: Many companies have sought to respond to shifting consumer tastes by investing in the development of more organic and other purportedly healthy products. Consumer research and customer surveys can help operators develop new product lines.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs by automating operations over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Wage costs have been declining over the long term, but an increase in small-scale production has actually raised the industry's overall labor intensity. Larger operators can typically automate a large portion of the production and canning processes.

FAQs.question: Does your company use SAP software systems to optimize all aspects of manufacturing, sales, inventory and distribution channels?
FAQs.answer: Logistics have been a major focus of automation over the past several years across the manufacturing and wholesale sectors generally. Logistic software can ensure efficiency from back-end production to front-end delivery.

FAQs.question: Have you had any regulatory expenses that have significantly impacted profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: The Food Safety Modernization Act increased compliance costs in the manufacture and distribution of grocery products.

FAQs.question: What effect have international tariffs had on your ability to import and export products?
FAQs.answer: Retaliatory tariffs from traditional US trading partners have the potential to hurt exports.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors?
FAQs.answer: Profit varies widely between slim margins for small scale producers and margins in excess of 20.0% for major companies. Depending on size, profit above or below industry benchmarks can indicate pricing power or weakness.

FAQs.question: How does your company compensate for seasonality of cash flow?
FAQs.answer: Demand for certain foods is highly seasonal; for example, many canned vegetables are sold mainly during the holiday season. Diversified product lines can help stabilize revenue trends.

FAQs.question: Have you introduced an organic product line to cater to health-conscious consumers? How can you better promote your organic products?
FAQs.answer: Due to the diverse range of products that industry operators produce, companies that differentiate their products are better able to maintain market share. Monitoring product sales data can help operator's determine more financially viable product lines.

FAQs.question: How can you attain economies of scale? How can you cut your production costs?
FAQs.answer: Larger companies typically have lower per-unit production costs because they are able to spread their costs over a large volume of output.

FAQs.question: Do you use fresh fruit and vegetables in your products? Do you add preservatives or syrups?
FAQs.answer: Companies fiercely compete based on the quality and taste of their products. Thus, using the best ingredients ensures that the end products will be of high quality.

FAQs.question: Do you target health-conscious consumers?
FAQs.answer: Consumers have become increasingly averse to inorganic preservatives.

FAQs.question: Are you able to pass on price increases to your consumers? How will you fare with a rise in fruit prices?
FAQs.answer: As people consume more fruits and vegetables, demand for canned fruits and vegetables increases as well. Increases in the price of fruit have a more immediate impact on consumers of fresh fruit, and therefore make industry products comparatively more affordable, boosting their appeal for cost-conscious consumers.

FAQs.question: What percentage of your products are currently sold at supermarkets? Do you have long-term supply contracts with grocery wholesalers?
FAQs.answer: Grocery wholesalers constitute the largest downstream market for the Canned Fruit and Vegetable Processing industry's products. Therefore, growth in the Grocery Wholesaling industry tends to significantly increase demand for industry products.
